newsitem.title: USA: CBOT board rescinds plan to extend day pit hours.
newsitem.headline: CBOT board rescinds plan to extend day pit hours.

text.p: The Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT) said its board of directors on Tuesday rescinded a proposal made last month to extend daytime pit trading hours for financial futures and options.

The proposal was part of a plan approved by the board on April 16 to restructure CBOT's trading hours by scrapping the evening open-outcry session and essentially replacing it with the Project A electronic after-hours trading system.
The plan to discontinue the evening session on April 2, 1998, pending a membership vote, is still in effect, the CBOT said.
"The board's decision comes after broad member input since our last meeting on the best way to structure our 24-hour trading day," CBOT chairman Patrick Arbor said in a statement.

Under the revised plan, daytime open-outcry trading hours for financial contracts, such as 30-year Treasury bond futures, would be unchanged, opening at 0720 CDT/1220 GMT and closing at 1400 CDT/1900 GMT. The April proposal had sought to extend the close by one hour.
Under the new plan, Project A session would start at 1430 CDT/1930 GMT and shut the next morning at 0645 CDT/1145 GMT.

Currently, the day pit trade is followed by the afternoon Project A session from 1430 CDT to 1630 CDT/2130 GMT, the night pit from 1820 CDT/2320 GMT to 2105 CDT/0205 GMT and the overnight Project A from 2200 CDT/0300 GMT to 0645 CDT.

CBOT officials could not immediately confirm whether a date for a membership vote had been set. Arbor said further review should be undertaken and additional user input gathered before a decision for a change would be enacted.
Scrapping the night pit trading has been a touchy issue putting futures commission merchants (FCMs) against the so-called "locals" and other traders.

FCMs have bemoaned that the session was a financial drain, given the steadily declining trading volume, while others still saw it as a valuable source of supplemental income and training ground for inexperienced traders.
